She and her husband work together to earned a living to finance the family's needs and expenses. 

Julia joined CEVI in order to gain access to the financial services offered by the organization. Now, she is asking for a loan worth 4000 PHP to buy additional fertilizers for her crops. She believes that this loan would be a great help in improving the productivity of their farm thus giving them more yield and profit.

Julia dreams of improving her business so that it will generate more money that will be used for their sustenance and for the educational expenses of her children.

loans.use: to buy additional fertilizers

loans.name: Ruzan

texts.en:
Ruzan and her husband are still running their trading business. Recently Ruzan has diversified her business assortment and now she sells not only shoes but also tracksuits. The main accent in her business is on children’s shoes as they are always in popular demand. Thanks to business income Ruzan and her husband keep their family and they were able to improve their living conditions: they changed their flat to bigger one, as now their son’s family lives with them as well. 

Ruzan spent her first Kiva loan to increase her business assortment. Now she is asking for $ 2,300 loan to buy children’s and student’s shoes ahead of the new academic year.

loans.use: to buy children’s and student’s shoes ahead of the academic year

loans.name: Ritah

texts.en:
Ritah is 32 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Ritah has been working hard to manage her poultry business, which sells eggs. 

To help expand her business, Ritah has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicks and poultry feed, and will help Ritah to generate greater profits which will help her add on to her poultry farm. Ritah hopes that in the future she will be able to continue to educate her kids. 

Ritah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ritah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and poultry feed

loans.name: Kadijatu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 30-year-old Kadijatu from Kandeh town Southern area in Bo. She is married with 4 children between the ages of 3 years and 13 years. Three of are her children attend school. 

Kadijatu runs a provision shop; she sells milk, sugar, Ovaltine and bread, etc. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business every day 14 hours a day. Her business is the only source of income she has.  She says that the main challenges to her business are transportation costs and competition in the market.

Kadijatu has requested a loan in order to buy more sugar, toothpaste, milk and cigarettes. The extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her welfare. In the future, she plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more sugar, toothpaste, milk and cigarettes.

loans.name: Benvenida

texts.en:
Benvenida is a 30-year-old married woman and a mother of three young children from Bohol, Philippines. She has been running a mini-grocery store for more than two years now. This venture is the source of their income.

Benvenida needs funds for her business to grow and expand. She is applying for a loan worth 12,000 PHP to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, rice, bread and snack foods to sell to the people in their community. Benvenida believes that if she is provided with financial support through this loan, she will be able to purchase more stocks to sell thus giving her more chance of increasing her sales.

Benvenida dreams of improving her business to generate more income. The additional income will be used to finance the education of her children and for reinvestment in the same business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, rice, bread and snack foods

loans.name: Mwarua

texts.en:
Mwarua is 49 years old, married. He has been a carpenter for the last seven years and he is doing great. 

This is his second business loan from KADET LTD to finance his business. He plans to purchase new hammers, nails and chisels. He will use the anticipated profit to educate his children and repay his loan. 


He hopes to gradually expand his business and be able to support his family with ease.

loans.use: to purchase new hammers, nails and chisels

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en:
Rashid is 37 years old and lives in the town of Abaita Ababiri in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 7 years, Rashid has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells a variety of different commodities. 

To help expand his business, Rashid has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food like bread and eggs to stock his store, and will help Rashid to generate greater profits and become more business-oriented. Rashid hopes that in the future he will be able to become rich and open up other stores. 

Rashid is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rashid who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more food to stock his store

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is a married woman who earns a living through operating a poultry business. She has been doing so for the past five years, and her focus is to open a retail shop. Dama buys young chickens from the locals and raises them before she sells them mostly to cafe operators. She describes theft to be her major challenge. 

Dama is a woman who is devoted to her business. She says that she at times walks long distances in the search for young chickens to increase her flock. Demand for chicken has increased, but she lacks enough capital to increase her flock. This is the reason for her requesting a loan in the amount of Ksh 30,000 to purchase chickens and chicken feed.

loans.use: to purchase chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is 35 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has seven children, all of whom who currently in school. For the past five years, she has worked hard at her charcoal-selling business. To help expand this business, she is requesting a loan for 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use this loan to increase her profits by buying more bags of charcoal to sell, and use the additional profits to go into the business of selling food as well as charcoal. In the future, she also hopes to build houses that she can rent. Mariam is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP), which primarily serves small entrepreneurs like her who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth  is a 30-year-old married woman. She has 2 children, 6 years old and 11 years old. She describes herself to be a determined woman. She operates a retail store where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for 12 years. 

Her business is located at a conducive business environment  and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more charcoal for resale. Her business goal is to be a supplier of charcoal  within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 24 years old and single. He is a dairy farmer and has been in the business for the past five years. He gets a monthly income of KES 8,000 from his business.

This is his second loan from KADET LTD. He repaid his previous loan well and in good time. He will use the loan amount to purchase a dairy cow for more milk production.

He hopes to be a famous farmer in his area.

loans.use: to purchase a  dairy cow

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 33 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 7 years, Joseph has been working hard to manage his hardware business, which sells doors and windows. 

To help expand his business, Joseph has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more metals for welding, and will help Joseph to generate greater profits and add more products to sell. Joseph hopes that in the future he will be able to build more rental houses. 

Joseph is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joseph who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more metals for welding

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 60 years old. He is married to Teresa and together they have two children aged 21 and 13 years old. He sells motorcycle spare parts and has been in the business for the past 12 years

This is his third loan with KADET LTD. He repaid his previous loans well and in good time. He will use the loan amount to purchase spare parts to stock for resale.

He hopes to purchase a pick-up to be used in his business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts to stock for resale.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en: Damaris is 43 years old, married and the mother of four children. For the last seven years she has earned a living by running a grocery business, and now makes KES. 30,000 a month. She is requesting her third loan from KADET LTD, for KES. 40,000, which she will use to buy more tomatoes, onions and vegetables to sell to her customers. She will take the profits she earns from this loan and reinvest them in her business. Her dream for the future is to have a happy family.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, onions and vegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 29 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 7 years, Rose has been working hard to manage her salon, where she dresses hair. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy cosmetics, weaves, and relaxers, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and help her purchase her basic needs. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to continue to educate her kids. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rose who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, weaves, and relaxers

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en: Jenifer lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is widowed and has four children, three of whom currently attend school. For the last three years, Jenifer has worked hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells drinks and household items. To help expand her business, Jenifer has requested a loan for 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more items to sell to her customers.  She hopes to generate greater profits and increased sales so that she can expand her store.  Jenifer is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP), which primarily serves small entrepreneurs like her who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys, 33, is married to Daniel and they are blessed with four children, ages 13, 11, 9 and 2. She owns rental houses and also runs a retail shop. She ventured into these businesses three years ago and earns a monthly income of KES 25,000. 

She has requested a second loan of KES 100,000 to purchase building materials to finish up the rental rooms. The anticipated profit will help her educate her children. Her dream is to be a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase building materials for finishing up her rental rooms.

loans.name: Hannifah

texts.en:
Hannifah lives in the town of Kasangati in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, all currently in school. For the past five years, Hannifah has been working hard to manage her poultry business, selling chickens and eggs. 

To help expand her business, Hannifah has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more feed for the chickens. This will help Hannifah generate greater profits and increase her chicken count which improves egg sales. Hannifah hopes that in the future she will be able to eradicate poverty. 

Hannifah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hannifah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more feed for chickens.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 34 years old and single. He owns a retail shop and the business has been profitable. Besides the retail business as his primary business, he also does farming and sells cash crops like maize, beans and potatoes.

This will be his second loan and he plans to use the loan to boost his farming business by buying fertilizer and seed for this planting season. In the future, Michael hopes to start a fertilizer-selling business.

loans.use: buy fertilizer and seed for his farming business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn, who lives in Talibon, Bohol, Philippines, is married and has four children, her eldest 17 and her youngest 6. She and her husband have been operating a fishing business for quite some time now, and she gives her best to help and support him in the pursuit of their needs.

Jocelyn is now requesting a loan to buy a new fish net and nylon to repair the old ones. This would be a great help in increasing the catch of her husband as she dreams of expanding their business to earn more for the family. She also wants to give her children a good education.

loans.use: to buy a new fish net and nylon to repair the old ones.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 48 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is widowed and has 7 children with one of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Jane has been working hard in her property management business, where she rents houses. 

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy cement and building materials to renovate her rental houses, and will help Jane to generate greater profits and increase her source of income so that she can build other rental houses. Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to buy another piece of land. 

Jane is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jane who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy cement and building materials to renovate her rental houses

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is 22 years old and single. He has a motorcycle transport business in Nyahururu town and has been in the business for two years.

This will be his first loan and he plans to buy a motorcycle for his transport business.With the anticipated profits he plans to invest more in his business.

In the future, Alex hopes to also have other businesses such as retail and wholesale businesses and make more income.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 35 years old, married, and blessed with four children aged 14, 10, eight and six years. She runs a retail shop where she sells a variety of goods. She started this business two years ago and earns a monthly income of KES 7,000. 

She has requested a first loan of KES 20,000 to purchase packets of tea leaves, sugar and bales of baking flour and maize flour. 

The anticipated profit will aid her to educate her children. Her dream is to one day purchase a piece of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase packets of tea leaves, sugar and bales of baking flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 45 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is widowed and has 4 children who are all currently in school. For the past 2 years, Juliet has been working hard to manage her leather shop, which sells leather products like shoes. 

To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more shoes to sell, and will help Juliet to generate greater profits and be able to renovate her rental homes. Juliet hopes that in the future she will be able to expand to sell all types of shoes. 

Juliet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Juliet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia  is a 38-year-old single woman. She has two children, ages 6 and 10. She describes herself to be a religious and faithful woman. She operates a retail store where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her primary customers are schools, shops and shopping malls. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy school uniform material. Her business goal is to venture into a retail store business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children .

loans.use: to buy school uniform material.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both currently in school. For the past few years, Sylvia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells household items and food stuffs. 

To help expand her business, Sylvia has requested a loan of 2500000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy drinks and other goods to sell. This will help Sylvia generate greater profits and narrow her capital gap. Sylvia hopes that in the future she will be able to have a wholesale shop. 

Sylvia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sylvia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy drinks and other goods to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more beauty products and increase her stock.

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley is now 34 years old and has a tailoring business in Nyahururu town. He is married to Lilian and they have a six-year-old child.

This being his second loan, he plans to expand his business by buying more stock of sewing materials and sewing items such as zips, hooks and sewing thread. He also plans to buy school materials and make school uniforms, hence distribute them to various schools.

In the future, Stanley hopes to get into wholesaling of tailoring accessories in Nyahururu town.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials and tailoring accessories.

loans.name: Rizza

texts.en:
Rizza is 29, married, and has three children ages 7, 4 and 2. They reside in Bohol, Philippines. Rizza has been a nipa weaver for 10 years. Nipa is a species of palm native to the coastlines and estuarine habitats of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The leaves are weaved and are sold for house roofs and other purposes. This business provides her with needed income. Rizza is applying for a loan of 8000 PHP to buy additional materials for weaving such as plastic straw and nylon. With this loan, Rizza will be able to increase her product output, thus giving her the chance to increase sales and profit.
Rizza hopes to expand her business to generate more income. She also wants to send her children to school for better education. She dreams of seeing her children as successful professionals someday.

loans.use: to buy additional materials for weaving such as plastic straw and nylon.

loans.name: Zymber

texts.en:
Zymber is 46 years old. He lives in Kosovo with his wife and two daughters ages eight years old and five years old. The younger girl has epilepsy.

They live in an area which is consistently poorer than the rest of the country according to all definitions of poverty. Zymer is extremely poor, despite his efforts to make a better life; he and his family are still struggling. 

Zymer works as a fireman in his municipality with a very low salary. Because his salary is not enough for their needs, he is working together with his family in the business of milk production, selling milk in his neighborhood. Zymber works with the desire to improve his situation in order to offer his family a better life.

With a goal to further grow his business, he requested a loan from KosInvest to renovate his stable. The income from the loan will help him to expand his stable. In the future he plans to invest more and increase the number of cows he keeps. In this way he will improve the welfare of his family.

Knowing that this is a Kiva loan, he wants to thank all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To renovate his stable

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Eva has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells household goods and cooking ingredients. 

To help expand her business, Eva has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock like cooking oil and spices, and will help Eva to generate greater profits and increase her capital stock. Eva hopes that in the future she will be able to be self-reliant. 

Eva is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Eva who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stock like cooking oil and spices

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children with 2 of them currently in school. For the past few years, Faith has been working hard to manage her clinic, where she carries out minor treatments. 

To help expand her business, Faith has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medicines for treatments, and will help Faith to generate greater profits and increase her capital stock. Faith hopes that in the future she will be able to be self-reliant. 

Faith is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Faith who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more medicines for treatment

loans.name: Ma. Cecilia

texts.en: Ma. Cecilia is 32 years old and comes from Talibon, Bohol. She is married and her husband work as a "tricycle" driver. She has daughter who is 3 years old. She has been engaged in a sari-sari store business (general store) for eight years now. Ma. Cecilia’s difficulties include her limited funds to buy stock on time. She is asking for a loan to buy rice, snack foods, canned goods, toiletries,  seasonings and soft drinks. In the future, she would like to make her store bigger, like a mini-grocery. Any additional income that she will generate will be used for family daily consumption and reinvestment in the same business.

loans.use: to buy rice, snack foods, canned goods, toiletries,  seasonings and soft drinks

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 35 years old married. She has four children. 

She runs a boutique business and has earned a monthly income of KES 50,000 for the last three years.

She has applied her third loan of KES 100,000 from KADET Ltd., with which she plans to purchase more stock of sweaters, skirts and blouses. 

The anticipated profits she will invest back into her business. Her dream is to have a happy family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of sweaters, skirts and blouses.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Rachel is thirty two years old married. She is a mother to four school going children.

For the last three years, Rachel has been earning a living in a green grocery business. She earns a monthly income of KES 2,800. She has applied for the first loan of 10,000 with KADET LTD, with which she plans to purchase more stock of onions, vegetables and tomatoes. She will use the profits to pay her children's school fees as well as to continue looking after her family. Her future hope is to expand the business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of onions, vegetable and tomatoes.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, one child currently in school. For the past three years, Patrick has been working hard to manage his electronics shop, where he sells second-hand phones. 

To help expand his business, Patrick has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more phones to sell, and will help Patrick to generate greater profits and increase his capital stock. Patrick hopes that in the future he will be able to open up another branch. 

Patrick is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Patrick who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more phones to sell

loans.name: Denice

texts.en:
Denice is a 26-year-old married man. He has a son. He describes himself as a determined man. 

He operates a retail store where he sells disinfectant and cleaning detergents. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located within a densely populated area. He describes his biggest business challenge as insufficient funds. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy detergents. His business goal is to be a distributor of detergents and disinfectants to schools and hotels within five years. He hopes that in the future he will buy land.

loans.use: to buy detergents.

loans.name: Sherry

texts.en:
Sherry is 34 years old. Sherry lives in Talibon, Bohol. She has one son who is 6 years old that she needs to support from her income.  

She makes a living out of her manicure and pedicure services. She also works as an Avon dealer. She sells lotion, body talc and cologne. 

She is asking for a loan  to buy more nail polish, lotion, body talc and cologne.

Any additional income will be used to finance her child’s schooling and the family's daily consumption and for reinvestment in the business and savings.

She dreams of improving her business so that her child will have a better future.

loans.use: to buy more nail polish, lotion, body talc and cologne.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry lives in the town of Wakiso in the Kampala East region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children, 3 of them currently in school. For the past 5 years, Henry has been working hard to manage his poultry business, where he raises broiler chickens and sells to locals. 

To help expand his business, Henry has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more birds and will help Henry to generate greater profits. He will also create more space for the birds to live. Henry hopes that, in the future, he will be able to grow his income after his investment in his business. 

Henry is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Henry who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more birds.

loans.name: Bonface

texts.en:
Bonface is a 40 year old married man. He has 4 children, with ages ranging from 5 years to 16 years. He describes himself to be an aggressive man. 

Bonface operates a retail store where he sells disinfectant and cleaning detergents. He has been involved in this business for 10 years and employs 1 staff member. His business is located at an industrial area and his primary customers are friends. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of funds for improving the business. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy disinfectants and detergents to resell. His business goal is to be importing raw materials for making detergents and disinfectants within 5 years. 

Bonface hopes that in the future, he will be able to educate his children with profits generated.

loans.use: to buy disinfectant and detergents.

loans.name: Anna Luz

texts.en:
Anna Luz is a 30-year-old married woman with a 4-year old child. She lives with her family in Bohol, Philippines. She has had a sari-sari store or mini-grocery store business for more than ten years now, selling goods to the people in her community.

Anna Luz is a hardworking woman who tries her best to earn a living so that she can help her husband in supporting the needs of the family.
 
Anna Luz is asking for a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, rice, snack foods, soda and others. With the loan, Anna Luz will be able to augment her stocks so that she can cater to more customers in their locality.

Anna Luz hopes to expand her business so that it will generate more income. Moreover, she wants to save for the education of her child.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, rice, snack foods and soda.

loans.name: Kifaalu

texts.en:
Kifaalu lives in the town of Wakiso in the Kampala East region of Uganda. He is single and has two children who are both currently in school. 

For the past 10 years, Kifaalu has been working hard to manage his bar, where he sells beers, spirits and soft drinks. 

To help expand his business, Kifaalu has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drinks for his bar, and it will help Kifaalu to generate greater profits and allow him to expand his business by serving more customers. Kifaalu hopes that in the future, he will be able to be self-reliant. 

Kifaalu is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Kifaalu who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more drinks for his bar.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 52 years old single with four children aged 32, 27, 24 and 18 years respectively. She sells milk at the main market, a business she started 12 years ago. She earns a monthly income of KES 32,000. 

Mary has requested for a second loan of KES 80,000 to buy more milk to sell. The profit she earns from this business will aid her in buying a dairy cow for efficient milk production. She dreams of being a farmer's dairy farmer.

loans.use: to purchase more milk to sell.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine hails from Talibon, Boho. She is 35 years old and is married with three children. Her eldest is 14 and the youngest is 2. She and her husband farm for a living. Geraldine is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and insecticide, which are necessary for her farm's healthy growth.

Geraldine relies on farming for her family’s needs. Therefore, she is determined to make a better profit out of her main livelihood. Her profit will used be for school fees, food and basic household needs.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Leoncia

texts.en:
Leoncia is a 38-year-old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She has a 13-year-old son. She is engaged in a recycling and scrap-buying business. Leoncia also raises hogs. 

Leoncia is asking for a loan worth 10,000 PHP to be used as additional capital for her recycling and scrap-buying business, to buy feeds for the hogs, and for the educational expenses of her son. Leoncia dreams of expanding her business to generate more revenue. She also wants to send her son to school for a better education.

loans.use: to be used as additional capital for her recycling and scrap-buying business, to buy feeds for her hogs, and for the educational expenses of her son

loans.name: Lokitela

texts.en:
Lokitela is 36 years old, from Nyahururu and he is married. He has four children who are all in school.

Lokitela has a retail business that he has been doing for the past two years. He has applied for his first loan from KADET LTD, to enable him to buy flour, sugar, soft drinks, etc. to add to his stock.

He hopes to see his business expand in the near future.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar and soft drinks.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia lives in the town of Kalerwe, in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, 1 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells household goods like soap and sugar. 

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more goods like eggs and bread to sell in her shop. This will help Lydia to generate greater profits and improve her customer base. Lydia hopes that, in the future, she will be able to grow her business enough so that she can send her kids to school. 

Lydia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lydia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more goods like eggs and bread to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock of maize beans and peas.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in a food vending business for more than 25 years now. She sells cooked foods to the people in the neighborhood. This provides her the income that she needs.

Currently, Elena lacks additional funds for the improvement and expansion of her business. She is asking for a loan worth 6,000 PHP to buy additional ingredients for food vending such as meat, vegetables, seasoning, etc. She is positive that, through this loan, she can make her business grow and prosper.

Elena dreams of expanding her business to generate more income so that she will become financially capable of sending her children to school.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for food vending such as meat, vegetables, seasoning, etc.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en: Rogelio has spent 22 years, most of his life, fishing in the town of Bien Unido, Bohol. He and his wife rely on this livelihood for an income. He is asking for a loan to buy gasoline and fishing nets for his business, as well as rice for family consumption. Rogelio is determined to raise the status of his life and that of his spouse. He is working so he can support his family. He hopes that he can save enough so he is prepared when they are blessed with a child in the future.

loans.use: to buy gasoline, fishing nets and rice

loans.name: Ninia

texts.en:
Ninia is from the town of Panglao, Bohol, Philippines. She has five young children. She has been raising hogs for some time now. This is one of the sources of her family's income.

Ninia needs funds for her business to grow. She is asking for a loan worth 7,000 PHP to buy feeds for the pigs and additional piglets to raise. She believes that this loan would be a great help in developing her business.

Ninia dreams of expanding her business so that it can augment her income and help her in sending her children to school.

loans.use: to buy feeds for the pigs and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 39 years old, married and has twin children. She has been operating a printing business for seven years, earning monthly income of KES 60,000.

Susan has applied for her first loan of KES 100,000 from KADET LTD, with which she plans to purchase more stock of computer installation and printing papers. She plans to open another cybershop with the anticipated profits from her business. For her future, she hopes to have a happy family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of computer installation and printing papers.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in the town of Nansana, in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, 2 of them currently in school. For the past 5 years, Florence has been working hard to manage her tailor shop, where she makes sweaters and other clothes. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to expand the business through buying more materials to make clothes. This will help Florence to generate greater profits after selling more clothes. Florence hopes that, in the future, she will be able to be self reliant. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Florence who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more materials to make clothes.

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en: Jesusa is a 42-year-old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She has four children. For more than ten years, she and her husband have been engaged in a fishing business. This is their source of income. Jesusa is a hardworking woman. However, she needs more funds for her business to grow. She is asking for a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy new fishing nets and other fishing equipment for her husband. Jesusa dreams of improving their lives and sending her children to school for a better education.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and other fishing equipment

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is a 22 year old single man. He describes himself to be a goal-oriented man. He operates a retail store where he sells plastic items such as basins, cups, plates, spoons, water storage containers, etc. He has been involved in this business for 1 year. His business is located within a market and his primary customers are local residents. 

Wilson describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more water storage containers of 20,000 litres so as to meet the increasing demands from his customers. His business goal is to run a similar retail store within 5 years. He hopes that, in the future, he will have a family and children.

loans.use: to buy more water containers with storage of 20 litres.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa, 68 years old, is from Talibon, Bohol. She is married and has seven adult children. 

In spite of her age, Josefa operates a sari-sari store and does rice farming, together with her husband, to earn a living. She is asking for a loan to buy merchandise like seasoning, canned products like milk, corned beef, sardines, snack food, chips and fertilizer for her farm. The additional capital will boost her business and will provide her and her husband with a healthy diet and an income.

loans.use: to buy merchandise like seasoning, canned products like milk, corned beef, sardines, snack food, chips and fertilizer.

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie is 40 years old and lives in Talibon, Bohol with her family. She is married and has four children, ages 6-20. Her husband works as a fisherman while Josie attends to her sari-sari store business.  

Josie is asking for a loan to buy snack food, toiletries, seasoning, canned goods and soft drinks that she can sell in her store. She dreams of improving her business so that she can have increased profits.

Any additional income will be used for the family's daily consumption, reinvestment into the same business,  school fees and savings.

loans.use: to buy snack food, toiletries, seasoning, canned goods and soft drinks.

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy is a resident in Panglao, Bohol, Philippines. She is a 38 year old married woman and a mother of six young children. She has been in the fishing business for 20 years now, since her husband is a fisherman.

Cristy is asking for a loan worth 12,000 PHP to buy new fishing nets for her husband's fishing and to buy school projects for her children. 

Cristy believes that this loan would really help her in realizing her dreams about improving their livelihood.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets.

loans.name: Janviere

texts.en:
Janviere is 47 years old. She has seven children, aged between 9 years and 24 years old, all of them are enrolled in school. With the loan she has requested, she will buy more bananas to sell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for the children. 

Janviere was very interested in requesting another loan, because the last one helped so much. She noticed a booming of the business, where the quantity of bananas sold was raised from 5 to 10 bananas per day, even the situation at home is also nice.

loans.use: to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Romana

texts.en:
Romana lives in Trinidad, Bohol. She is single and enjoys running a sari-sari store. She is challenged by lack of funds to reinvest into her business. She also faces stiff competition in her community.

Romana is asking for a loan to buy rice, soft drinks and wine, which sells the most in her store right now. A loan will enable Romana to expand her business by purchasing more inventory to better compete and attract more customers that visit her area. The additional income will be used to reinvest in her store stand to ensure that she remains competitive. 

Romana will be able to provide for her needs of healthy food and to save for the future.

loans.use: to buy rice, soft drinks and wine.

loans.name: Ma. Victoria

texts.en:
Ma. Victoria is from Panglao, Bohol, Philippines. She is a 27 year old married woman and a mother of two young children, ages 7 and 2. Ma. Victoria has been in a food vending business for more than three years now, selling snack foods to the people in their community.

Ma. Victoria is asking for a loan worth 9,000 PHP to buy additional food stocks to cook (for her food vending business) such as ripe bananas, sugar, cooking oil and others. This loan will be a great help for her in improving their livelihood and standard of living. She also wants to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy additional food stocks to cook (for her food vending business) such as ripe bananas, sugar, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 33 year old business man. He is married to Irene who is a business lady. They are blessed with two children, aged 10 and one year respectively. He has been selling shoes for the past five years with a monthly income of KES 20,000, which he uses to support his family members. 

John is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD., after being introduced by an existing KADET customer. John will use the loan to buy more stock of shoes. With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his children. 

John's hopes and dreams are to expand his shoe selling business and to improve the family's living standard.

loans.use: to buy more stock of shoes.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Like most people in Trinidad, Teodora relies on farming for an income. She makes a living by planting and harvesting rice. She is proud of her livelihood, for this has been her source of income for a long time now. 

Teodora is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer for her farm. This is necessary so that her crops will grow robust and have a high yield. Not only will the farm provide an income, it will provide food for her family too, out of their harvest. She also plans to expand her farm so that she can plant more crops to help her business become bigger and better.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en:
Mediatrice is aged 36. She is a mother of five children, all are enrolled in schools. 

Mediatrice wants the loan to buy more beans and sorghum to sell. She has been running this business for the past four years. The profits from the business will be used to renovate the house.

loans.use: to buy more beans and sorghum to sell.

loans.name: Jariah

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Jariah from Kandeh town in the southern area of Bo, Sierra Leone. She is married and has five children between the ages of 10 and 19. Three of her children are currently attending school. She also has two dependents living with her: relatives from the village. She began her business because her husband is out of a job. She wanted to generate an income to support their family.

Jariah runs a provision shop at her house; she sells milk, sugar, bread, and soft drinks. She has been running this business for 15 years. She works at the business every day from 6:00 am until 11:00 pm. Jariah and her family are living in the shop. She does not have any source of income except her business. She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and insufficient capital to invest in her business.

Jariah has requested a loan in order to buy more milk, sugar, bread, and soft drinks. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and improve her welfare. In the future, she plans to be a supplier. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more milk, sugar, bread, and soft drinks

loans.name: Viola

texts.en: Viola is a married woman with four adult children from Bien Unido, Bohol. She and her husband have a fishing business. She is asking for a loan to buy gasoline, to repair their fishing net, and to buy fish hooks for a greater catch. She works very hard in helping sell what her husband catches. With a loan Viola will be able to purchase nylon needed to repair their fishing nets and improve their productivity. Because of the loan, Viola will be able to grow her fishing business, gaining new customers and increasing her income. With the additional income, Viola will be able to provide for all of her family's daily needs and create a savings fund.

loans.use: to buy gasoline, repair their fishing net, and buy fish hooks

loans.name: Joenalyn

texts.en:
Joenalyn is a resident of Bohol, Philippines. She is 31 years old and a mother of three young children. She has been engaged in a fish selling or vending business for more than ten years now. This provides her the income that she needs for her family. 

Joenalyn is asking for a loan worth 19,000 PHP to buy more fish to sell and to buy feed for the hogs. With this loan she will be able to augment her income. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more. Joenalyn wants to send her children to school for their bright future.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell and to buy feed for the hogs.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is 50 years old. She sells beans and sorghum.  

Joice is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy more beans and sorghum to sell. The profits from the business will be used to provide food for her family.

loans.use: to purchase beans and sorghum to sell.

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.en:
57 year old Rodrigo has been a farmer in San Miguel, Bohol for 32 years now. He grows rice, both for an income and for personal consumption. Rodrigo hopes that he can prepare his land again for the planting season without having to worry about the expenses. He is asking for a loan to buy healthy seedlings, fertilizer and insecticides for his farm. Rodrigo knows the importance of these necessities for his farm's success. 

In the future, Rodrigo would like to expand his farm for a better income, so he can be a better provider for his family's needs.

loans.use: to buy healthy seedlings, fertilizer and insecticide.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
Eufemia, 60 years old, is from San Miguel, Bohol. She is married and has two sons, ages 19 and 22. Eufemia's husband works as a farmer. She is currently engaged in a sari-sari store business that sells basic household commodities. 

Eufemia is asking for a loan to buy canned goods, noodles and beverages. A profitable business will support her family, in terms of food and the education of her children. In the future, Eufemia hopes to make her store bigger and offer more merchandise for her customers to choose.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, noodles and beverages.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en:
Meet 52-year-old Baby from Kandeh town Southern area in Bo, Sierra Leone. She is widowed and has 7 children between the ages of 15 years and 38 years. Three of her children are currently attending school. 

In 2000, Baby established her food stuff business. She began her business because, after the death of her husband, she decided to a start business to raise income to support her family. She works at the business every day except holidays. She says that the main challenges to her business are that the road network is poor and transportation is costly.

Baby requires a loan in order to buy more garie, palm oil, and bundle water. She opens that the extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her family's standard of living. In the future, Baby plans to open a shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more garie, palm oil, and bundle water.

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad has a rice farm and would like start planting again soon. She is 57 years old and from San Miguel, Bohol. Rice farming has been her business since she raised her five, now grown, children. 

Caridad is asking for a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and to pay for the labor of her hired help. The income she earns will allow her to provide a better and more secure life for her family. In addition, she can reinvest her profit in the same business.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and to pay for the labor of her hired help.

loans.name: Flaviana

texts.en:
Flaviana, 55 years old, is from Talibon, Bohol. For many years she has been engaged in the buying and selling of scrap materials in her place. She also supplies mango, bananas and coconut in the market. She enjoyed what she is doing and would like to explore more options to make it even more profitable. 

Flaviana is asking for a loan to buy assorted scrap items, mangoes, bananas and coconut. Flaviana's income will provide her family with nutritious food and savings.

loans.use: to buy assorted scrap items, mangoes, bananas and coconut.

loans.name: Terry

texts.en:
For eight years, Terry worked as a FedEx driver. But when he left the business in 1992, Terry realized he liked the business so much that he didn’t want to give it up.  So he returned in 1994 as a contractor. 

In 2007, however, Terry sold his route and trucks to Pry Trucking Inc. to keep his business afloat as he didn’t have enough payroll to pay his 13 employees. Shortly after, his wife developed his contracting business: Triple L Contracting. Terry then returned to FedEx delivering packages to homes and businesses in Cape Girardeau, Missouri. 

Besides the raise in pay he gains from contracting, Terry said he decided to become an entrepreneur because he enjoys interacting with his clients. He says, “Basically, I have served the same customers since 1984. It’s almost like a family thing. We know each other.”

With his 13-member team, Terry says his business is growing; he plans on conducting interviews within the next two months. Triple L Contracting is expected to grow 47 percent in the next five years, he says, in which time he plans to hire four more drivers and purchase four more trucks. 

However, Terry has never had much luck with money, he says. As he knew he needed cash flow to fix his financial situation and keep his business running, Terry decided to obtain a loan. After hearing about Accion Texas Inc. from one of his employees, he inquired about one and was approved.

The loan helped Terry with operating expenses and payroll.  “It allowed me to take care of business,” he says.  Without it, he believes some things would have been put off for months.

loans.use: to pay operating expenses and payroll

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina is a 54 year old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She has been running a sari-sari store, or grocery store, for more than 20 years now. She sells rice, canned goods and other snack foods to the people in their place. This is her source of income. 

Justina is applying for a loan worth 20,000 PHP to buy more items to sell like rice, canned goods, noodles, soda and others. This loan would be a great help for her especially because it will allow her to buy more stock to sell.

Justina dreams of expanding her business. She also plans on saving some of her income for future use.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like rice canned goods, noodles, soda and others.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en:
For the past two years, sisters Lupita (right) and Silvia (left) have operated their janitorial company, Smacs Group LLC, with the help of six subcontractors. Specializing in commercial cleaning, including post-construction clean-up, window washing, power washing, and parking lot sweeping, Smacs is the parent company that has another two divisions consisting of office and residential cleaning in San Antonio, Texas. It is also certified by the Small Minority & Women-Owned Business Enterprise Program.

Though they have a successful business now, the sisters struggled for many years.  Originally from Guanajuato, Mexico, the two came to Texas 23 years ago when their mother decided to remarry.  The original plan was to return to Mexico after obtaining American residency. But that didn’t happen.  For 15 years, Lupita cleaned houses on her own and trained four women to start their own businesses.  (Three of the women are still in business.)  

In order to work more effectively with her American (and non-Spanish speaking) clients, she enrolled at San Antonio College to learn English.  When she mastered the language, she switched from doing residential cleaning to post-construction and other commercial clean-up. Together with her sister Silvia, who was the first in her family to graduate from college and has a BBA in business administration from The University of Texas at San Antonio, they created a mission and vision statement and reconstructed the business. 

With their Accion Texas Inc. loan, the women plan to purchase two or three backpack-type vacuums to make work easier on employees. “We don’t want them to be on their knees. It’ll improve the quality of work and then service. It’s a domino effect,” Silvia said. “We tell our employees to always remember that we are not in the cleaning business, we’re in the customer service business.” 

The Accion loan will help the women do more work in a shorter amount of time without compromising the service, Silvia said. Without help, it would have taken the women longer to purchase vacuums, or even begin to research pricing. Silvia said: “We’re very grateful to Accion for giving us a loan. We hope it continues to provide this service to the small business community.”

loans.use: to purchase backpack-type vacuums for their cleaning business.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en:
Ana Maria is an artisan who specializes in decoupage home accents, including boxes, wall decor, and trays. She would like to invest in the purchase of raw materials, such as pinewood, iron fixtures, and prints. To expand production she would also like to offer jobs to other artisans.

Ana Maria has been selling through NOVICA since 2004. This is her story:

"For as long as I can remember, I've been around arts and crafts. My whole family produced something and, when we'd visit our relatives, my cousins and I would make something for fun. After I married, my husband and I created various kinds of handicrafts. I began making decorative boxes, painted by hand with different finishes. Today I create boxes with classic motifs and an antique feel."

"Thank you for supporting small business artisans like me through interest-free microcredits, but, more than anything, thank you for your faith in me."

Use the link below to view Ana Maria's decoupage home accents on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/index.cfm?faid=4592

loans.use: to purchase raw materials and bring new artisans into her workshop

loans.name: Candida

texts.en:
Candida is from Panglao, Bohol, Philippines. She is 52 years old and a mother of four children. She has been engaged in a sari-sari store, or variety store, business for more than five years now. She is also in a fish vending business.

Candida is asking for a loan worth 5,000 PHP to buy more items to sell like canned goods, rice and others. She wants to augment her income so that she can alleviate their standard of living. She hopes to experience a fullness of life with her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like canned goods, rice and others.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 31 year old single woman. She has 3 children, with ages ranging from 7 years to 12 years. She describes herself to be faithful and honest woman. 

Elizabeth operates a retail store where she sells dresses. She has been involved in this business for 4 years and employs 1 staff member. Her business is located within a residential area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insecurity and insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy clothes materials and a sewing machine. Her business goal is to run a dress making training school within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, she will be financially stable .

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.en:
Gregorio weaves traditional Zapotec rugs from wool tinted with organic dyes. He would like to invest in raw materials and build another loom. He also plans to use some of the funds to give maintenance to the looms he has, and to invite other weavers in the village to assist him.

Gregorio has been selling through NOVICA since 2004. This is his story:

"My grandmother would take me to buy wool. She'd wash it, card it, spin it and dye the yarn. By the age of 12, I could reach the pedals of the handloom. Ever since, I've woven rugs and now my sons have also learned our craft. My favorite patterns are of mountains and rows of diamonds because they remind me a lot of my father. I feel proud that my sons also weave. We are able to support our families without having to leave home."

"I am grateful for the confidence you have in me, in my work, and in the weavers who collaborate with me. You are helping me to continue doing what I love and making it possible for me to teach this craft to others."

Use the link below to view Gregorio's rugs on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/index.cfm?faid=4534

loans.use: to purchase raw materials and a new loom for his rugs

loans.name: Gliceria

texts.en:
Gliceria is a 63 year old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in a food vending business for more than ten years now, selling snack foods to the people in their community. This is her source of income. 

Gliceria is asking for a loan worth 6,000 PHP to buy more ingredients for her food vending business. With the loan she will able to increase her sales, thus improving her profit. She dreams of expanding her business to generate more income. She also plans to save.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Israel

texts.en:
Israel specializes in handwoven rugs in Mexico's Zapotec tradition. He would like to build new looms for the workshop and stock up on wool and the natural materials used for dyes.

Israel has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story:

Israel and his family have been weaving Zapotec rugs for many generations. "Not one of us has ever hesitated to become a rug weaver. We have all grown up watching our parents and grandparents weave and, because it is an enjoyable process, we have followed in our parents' footsteps as adults. During the weekends we teach our children this same art form that has been passed down through many generations. Our children are learning in school that they have opportunities to try other types of work as well, but we would not be surprised if they eventually decide to become rug makers, following the tradition of our ancestors. We are all involved in every aspect of weaving, from washing the raw wool when it arrives at shearing time, to carding it carefully and dyeing it in many beautiful shades before weaving begins. We are especially careful to choose the right colors for each rug – we put careful consideration into this artistic aspect of the rug-making process."

"We are very grateful for this help. Thanks to our customers, we've been able to improve our rugs over the years and we hope to continue. Thank you!"

Use the link below to view Israel's rugs on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/index.cfm?faid=339

loans.use: to build new looms and stock up on raw materials for his rugs

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco specializes in handcrafted sterling silver jewelry. He would like to invest in a bulk purchase of silver to expand production.

Francisco has been selling through NOVICA since 2004. This is his story:

"I am the second generation of jewelers in my family, and now my daughters have also chosen this vocation. My designs are inspired by pre-Hispanic codices and the folklore of my country that I love so much. I sign my work as 'Citlali', meaning 'Star' in the Nahuatl language, so everyone wearing my designs has a star to keep them company."

"I feel honored to be considered a recipient of this interest-free microcredit. I am confident it will help us grow as we face some challenges at the moment that are affecting production."

Use the link below to view Francisco's silver jewelry on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/index.cfm?faid=4397

loans.use: to purchase silver in bulk and expand production of his jewelry

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is a 32 year old married woman. She has a son who is 3 years old. She describes herself to be an honest and business-minded woman. She operates a retail store where she sells items such as sugar, salt, flour, sodas etc. She has been involved in this business for 7 years. Her business is located within a viable business area and her primary customers are local residents. 

Faith describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more household items. Her business goal is to improve her retail store business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful in her business.

loans.use: to buy more household items.

loans.name: Beatrice Musabi

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 44 year old married woman. She has 4 children, with ages ranging from 5 years to 18 years. She describes herself to be a visionary woman. 

Beatrice operates a retail store where she sells items such sugar, salt, rice etc. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located within a viable business area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be poor infrastructure of roads and insecurity within the business environment. She will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy maize and beans to resell. Her business goal is to improve her retail store within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will have expanded her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize and beans.

loans.name: Fredrick Osore

texts.en:
Fredrick is a 26 year old married man. He describes himself to be a visionary man. He operates a retail store where he sells clothes and bags. He has been involved in this business for 3 years. His business is located within a busy market and his primary customers are local residents. 

Fredrick describes his biggest business challenge to be poor infrasture of roads that connect to his business premises. He will use the KES 35,000 loan to buy more bags to resell. His business goal is to improve his business within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will have expanded his business with profits generated.

loans.use: to increase his stock of clothes.

loans.name: Emilly

texts.en:
Emilly is a 57 year old married woman. She has 4 children, with ages ranging from 18 years to 30 years. She describes herself to be a visionary woman. 

Emilly operates a retail store where she sells items such as food and milk. She has been involved in this business for 4 years and employs 1 staff member. Her business is located within a busy market and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be quick spoiling of food. She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy a fridge. 

Emilly's business goal is to improve her business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will have expanded her business.

loans.use: to buy a fridge.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed is a 35-year-old married man. He has 4 children and 3 are enrolled in school. His wife's name is Mwanasha, a house wife. Mohamed operates a coconut business. He has worked in this business for 4 years. His primary customers are the people from the neighboring country. Mohamed's other source of income includes sales from farm produce. He describes his greatest business challenge to be price fluctuation and his highest monthly expenses are food and school fees. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Mohamed will use the Kes 50,000 loan to add more stock by buying 200 pieces of coconuts. Mohamed aspires to hire more employees in the future. He joined Yehu because of its product variety and policies.

loans.use: to buy 200 pieces of coconuts for sale

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en:
Mwanamkasi is 35 and is a very enterprising and hard-working woman. She has three children all of whom are in school. She owns her own house, and what she wants most is for her children to become professionals.

Mwanamkasi has operated a food stall for three years. Over that time, she says she has strengthened her sales techniques. She knows she has to work hard to be able to be successful in this type of business and she hopes to keep her customers. In the future, she wants to have her own hotel.

Mwanamkasi plans to use this loan to buy wheat flour, rice,meat, and other ingredients, and she is very happy to have enough financial support that could enable her to get ahead in her work. She promises to make her loan repayments in a punctual manner.

loans.use: buy more food ingredients

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica, age 53, is married and lives with their 7 children, three of whom attend school. She runs a business which she started 10 years ago, selling clothes. She also operates a kiosk. It is in this area that she wants to expand. Even though Monica never finished school, she has succeeded by working about 4 hours a day and keeping up with her housework and caring for her 3 children who still live with them. Her son mostly assists her in operating the kiosk. 

Despite the long days and all the hard work, she dreams of making her business grow and achieving a more dignified life for her family. For this purpose, she is requesting a loan from Kiva so that she can increase the variety of her products and improve their quality. She hopes to buy sugar, flour and other fast-selling products. Monica will be able to have more income and a greater margin of utility in order to offer her children a more promising future.

loans.use: to buy sugar, flour and other fast-selling products.

loans.name: Macario

texts.en: Macario is a resident in Bohol, Philippines. He has been in the fishing business for more than 20 years now. This is the source of his income. Macario is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP to buy new fishing nets and fuel for his fishing boat. With this loan and a new fish net, Macario will be able to enhance his catch, thus giving him more profit. Macario dreams of expanding his business in order to experience fullness of life with his family.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets and fuel for his fishing boat

loans.name: Galina

texts.ru:
Галина замужем. У нее есть взрослая дочь Яна. Галина имеет собственный бизнес.

Галина продает детскую одежду на центральном рынке города. У нее свое торговое место и опыт работы 20 лет.  Галина знает на какой товар есть спрос. Она трудолюбивая и ответственная.

Галина просит предоставить ей кредит в сумме 21000 гривен  на закупку товара к школьному сезону. Кредит помжет ей увеличить прибыль и тем самым улучшить быт ее семьи.
texts.en: Galina is married and has an adult daughter, Yana.  Galina has her own business.  She sells children's clothing at the city's central market.  She has her own retail space and 20 years of work experience.  Galina knows what merchandise is in demand.  She is hardworking and responsible.  Galina is requesting a loan in the amount of 21,000 hryvnia to purchase merchandise for the school season.  The loan will help her to increase her profit and, thus, improve her family's welfare.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for the school season

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is 38 years old, married, and says that she has four children. Mwanaisha’s family lives in the village of Msambweni and she says that she has had a food stall business which has been operational for the past two years.


Mwanaisha works a lot, especially now that the holidays are almost here, when food and beverage sales increase considerably. She considers herself to be a very hardworking and enterprising woman who struggles to provide her family with all the best and thus repay them for everything they have done for her.


She is grateful to Yehu Microfinance and Kiva for the support provided to her business. With this loan requested, she would like to buy meat, condiments, bread products and other ingredients needed to prepare her dishes.

loans.use: to buy meat, condiments, bread products and other ingredients needed to prepare her dishes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fabric, smoked fish, dried fish, cosmetics

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.ru:
Гулнора жительница города Истаравшан. Ей 49 лет. Она замужем. У нее двое детей. Ее муж вместе с сыном находятся на заработках за рубежом. Сама Гулнора имеет среднее образование. Она в основном занимается купле-продажей крупнорогатого скота. Гулнора разводит скот у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности она занимается три года. 
Гулнора просит кредит для закупа коровы и теленка.
texts.en: Gulnora is a resident of the city of Istaravshan.  She is 49 years old, married and has two children.  Her husband and son work abroad.  Gulnora has a secondary education.  She is primarily involved in buying and selling cattle.  Gulnora breeds livestock at home and has been in this business for three years.  She is requesting this loan to buy a cow and a calf.

loans.use: to buy a cow and a calf

loans.name: Jesus

texts.es: El Sr. Jesús tiene 52 años tiene 2 hijos que son de las edades de 12, y 15 años,  el se dedica  a la  venta y  crianza de cerdos en la localidad de Rio Seco, este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, el Sr. Jesús va a usar este préstamo para la compra de cerdos para su negocio, su razón para solicitar este préstamo es la falta de capital para la compra de cerdos, el Sr. Jesús enfrenta retos en su negocio que son mejorar su calidad de vida y  va a utilizar los beneficios para mejorar la calidad en la alimentación de sus cerdos,  su deseo es poder tener una granja donde pueda criar cantidad de cerdos para que de esta manera pueda mejorar su estabilidad económica.
texts.en: Jesús is 52 years old and has two children ages 12 and 15. He raises and sells pigs for a living in the town of Rio Seco. This loan is his first sequence within the institution. Jesús is going to use this loan to buy pigs for his business. His reason for requesting this loan is due to a lack of capital to buy the pigs. Jesús faces challenges in his business including improving quality of life. He is going to utilize the benefits to improve the quality of food for his pigs. He wants to be able to have a farm where he can raise a high quantity of pigs so that in this way he can improve his economic stability.

loans.use: to raise pigs.

loans.name: Sohibjon

texts.ru:
Сохибчон это человек, который любит работать усердно. На протяжении одного года, он был занят торговлей. Сохибчон занимается торговлей запчастей автомобилей. У него имеется много клиентов.

У Сохибчона большая семья. У него трое детей и любимая жена. Его жена домохозяйка. Он очень сильно любит свою семью. Сохибчон ведет свой бизнес один. Он является единственным кормильцем в семье. Сохибчон просит кредит на покупку необходимых запчастей с целью увеличения ассортимента, чтобы не потерять своих клиентов. Он ждет вашей помощи.
texts.en: Sohibjon is a person, who loves to work hard.  He has been involved in sales for one year.  Sohibjon is involved in selling automotive spare parts.  He has many customers.  Sohibjon has a large family.  He has three children and a beloved wife.  His wife is a homemaker.  He loves his family very much.  Sohibjon runs his business by himself.  He is the sole provider for the family.  Sohibjon is requesting this loan to purchase necessary spare parts in order to expand his selection and retain his customers.  He awaits your help.

loans.use: to purchase necessary spare parts

loans.name: Sandra Suyapa

texts.es:
La señora Sandra de 30 años de edad, es casada vive con su esposo y sus cinco hijos en su casa de habitación ubicada en una colonia de San Lorenzo al sur de Honduras, se dedica desde hace unos 3 años a la venta de detergentes y abarrotaría en general su venta es en su casa y también sale a vender a los barrios y colonias de San Lorenzo.
Doña Sandra esta solicitando 6,000.00 para compra de maíz, arroz, azúcar, manteca, huevos, detergente, jabón, papel higiénico, pastas y otros productos de consumo básico.
Doña Sandra con el apoyo de este préstamo desea aumentar su negocio y obtener mejores ganancias, Doña Sandra es una mujer muy responsable ya tiene varios años de trabajar con PRISMA y se siente muy contenta ya que se siente apoyada por este tipo de prestamos.
El sueño de Doña Sandra es mejorar su casa y que su familia este bien.
San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2012.
texts.en:
Sandra is 30 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and her five children in her house located in a neighborhood of San Lorenzo in the south of Honduras. For three years, she has sold detergent and general groceries. Her store is in her house, and she also goes out to sell to the neighborhoods of San Lorenzo.

Sandra is asking for 6,000 lempiras in order to buy corn, rice, sugar, butter, eggs, detergent, soap, toilet paper, pasta, and other basic consumer products. 

With the help of this loan, Sandra wants to increase her business and earn more income. Sandra is a very responsible woman, since she has worked with PRISMA for several years. She is very happy because she feels supported by these kinds of loans.

Sandra's dream is to improve her house and for her family to be well.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - July 2012.

loans.use: to buy corn, rice, sugar, butter, eggs, detergent, soap, toilet paper, pasta, and other basic consumer products

loans.name: Estrella Group

texts.en:
Estrella is 63 years old and lives in Pan-ay, Clarin. She is married and has three children. For the past twenty years she has farmed fruit and vegetable crops to earn a living. 

Estrella has been a member of PMPC for three years. She and another woman have formed a two-member group. Although they are borrowing as a group, each of them has her own business.

As leader of their group, Estrella is applying for a loan of 12,000 PHP. She will use her portion to buy organic and commercial fertilizers. In the future Estrella hopes to save for future emergencies.

loans.use: to buy organic and commercial fertilizers.

loans.name: Eilen Enith

texts.es: Eilen de 21 años de edad,  desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche trabaja en su heladería, con el fin de generar mayor bienestar a su familia conformada por su cónyuge y sus dos pequeños hijos. Su negocio lo inició hace 7 meses y está ubicado en su casa, lo cual le permite atender transversalmente las actividades, domésticas, productivas, reproductiva y sociales en su comunidad. En su negocio vende helados, paletas, confitería además de hielo. Su punto comercial es una oportunidad para agregar productos que usualmente sus vecinos compran como variedades, artículos de fantasía femenina y papelería en general. Eilen tiene la meta de crecimiento en su mente pero su principal desafío es no tener el capital de trabajo suficiente conque impactar el potencial mercado. Esta es justamente la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace ala Fundación Mario santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará artículos de miscelánea, productos de heladería y mecatos o golosinas, dulces y comestibles procesados industrialmente. Su sueño es es apoyar cada vez mas a su familia, provisionando a sus hijos de tanto bienestar como el que ella pueda darle, para que en un futuro sean exitosos.
texts.en:
Eilen is 21 years old. She works in her ice cream shop from 7 in the morning until 9 in the evening, because she wants to create better well-being situation for her family. Her family is composed by her husband and her two small children.

She started her business 7 months ago, it is located in her house which allows her to attend at various times to her home chores, productive, reproductive and social activities within her community.

In her business she sells ice creams, ice lollies, sweets and ice. The place where she is located creates a big opportunity to add products that her neighbours usually buy like fantasy jewelry, general stationary and a variety of other products.
